events.summary: TV division loss forecast narrows but margins still negative
events.description: At a Dec 1 2010 analyst day Philips said its TV business would lose €60-90 m in 2010 on \~€3 bn revenue, implying an adjusted EBITA margin of −2 % to −3 %.
events.snippet: TV unit margin −2 % to −3 %; €60–90 m loss.

events.summary: Samsung and LG surpass 40% global TV share
events.description: Market share data showed Samsung and LG jointly captured over 40 % of global TV shipments, signaling dominance by scale players.
Internal supply‑chain analysis showed LED package costs had decreased by 60 % between 2009 and 2013, improving gross margins.

events.summary: EU energy directives boost LED demand
events.description: The EU announced phase‑outs for halogen bulbs by 2016, accelerating commercial adoption of LED lighting solutions.

events.summary: Lighting sales slip 1 % YoY; EBITA margin 9.7 %
events.description: Q3 2014 results showed Lighting comparable sales −1 % YoY despite LED +28 %; adjusted EBITA margin hit 9.7 %.
Investment banks issued reports valuing Philips higher on a sum‑of‑the‑parts basis if lighting were separated.
Philips' Q2 2018 earnings showed the health technology segment grew revenues by 12 %, outpacing legacy units.

events.summary: Analysts initiate coverage on Philips as health‑tech pure play
events.description: Several brokerages upgraded Philips to 'buy' following the spin‑off, citing strong health‑tech market fundamentals.
Philips R\&D team published a paper showing a 20 % resolution gain in ultra‑high‑field MRI magnets.

events.summary: WHO projects 30 % rise in MRI demand by 2025
events.description: A WHO demographic report forecasted a 30 % increase in MRI utilization in OECD countries over five years.

events.summary: Tesla Roadster launch proves EV viability
events.description: The December 2009 launch of the Tesla Roadster demonstrated electric cars could match performance of ICE vehicles.
Panasonic demonstrated a new 18650 lithium‑ion cell with 15 % higher energy density at CES 2010.

events.summary: TV business posts \$913 m operating loss
events.description: Ahead of its plasma exit Panasonic disclosed its TV division lost about \$913 m in the prior FY—one driver behind shuttering the business.
In April 2014, Panasonic's board green-lit the €1.2 bn purchase of AU Automotive.
EU regulators gave antitrust approval for Panasonic’s AU Automotive acquisition in July 2014.

events.summary: Tesla investor day signals cell demand surge
events.description: At Tesla’s June 2017 Investor Day, management forecasted a doubling of battery cell needs by 2020.

events.summary: Panasonic board approves ₿500 m battery capex
events.description: In May 2017, Panasonic earmarked \$500 m for new EV cell production capacity.
A March 2019 pilot of Panasonic’s AI platform yielded a 15 % reduction in warehoused stock.

events.summary: Gartner names digital supply-chain top trend
events.description: In August 2019, Gartner identified AI-driven supply chains as the #1 digital priority for manufacturing.

decisions.rationale: Philips sells a majority stake in its HDTV business to TPV Technology, marking its strategic withdrawal from consumer-electronics TV manufacturing.

deltas.metric: Adjusted EBITA Margin gap vs Vision-2010 target

decisions.rationale: Philips announces the break-up of its 120-year-old company into two entities—standalone lighting and combined healthcare/consumer—so each can pursue distinct capital and growth strategies.

decisions.option: Demerge lighting division as Philips Lighting N.V.
decisions.rationale: Completing the 2014 plan, Philips floats 25 % of its lighting arm in an IPO—unlocking €3.4 bn in value and cementing its pure-play HealthTech focus.
Alongside the lighting spin-off, Philips merges its healthcare and consumer-lifestyle operations into a stand-alone HealthTech business to capture higher multiples.
Philips launches a €500 m R\&D program for its ultra‑high‑field, helium-free MRI platform following promising early demonstrations and rising clinical demand.

decisions.option: Partner with Tesla for EV batteries
decisions.rationale: Panasonic and Tesla announce a multi-year collaboration to co-develop nickel-based lithium-ion cells tailored for electric vehicles.
Panasonic commits to shutter its loss-making plasma-panel operations by end-of-March 2014, reallocating resources to higher-margin electronics.
Panasonic buys AU Automotive to bolster its in-vehicle electronics lineup and capture synergies with its growing EV-battery business.

decisions.option: Invest in Gigafactory EV battery plant
decisions.rationale: Panasonic commits capital to scale cell output at Tesla’s Nevada Gigafactory, targeting cost-parity with ICE by 2020.
A March 2019 pilot shows 15 % inventory reduction; Panasonic rolls out AI across global supply to boost responsiveness to EV demand swings.

transitions.reason: TV divestiture freed capital for Lighting/HealthTech split
Spin-off IPO executed to unlock value
Completed separation enabled HealthTech pure-play branding
HealthTech focus drove major R\&D investment
Strategic focus shifted to EV batteries from plasma TVs
Resources reallocated to automotive electronics M\&A
Synergies with Tesla partnership justified capacity build-out
